app.title: OpenKernel EDU
app.subtitle: Learn Computer Science with Emoji
app.tagline: The world's most accessible CS education platform

welcome.hero_subtitle: No programming experience needed. No English required. Just emoji.
welcome.why_universal_desc: Emoji are understood by 6.5 billion people worldwide. Learn to code without language barriers.
welcome.why_everyone_desc: From age 5 to 95. Visual, intuitive, and fun with immediate feedback on everything you do.
welcome.why_real_cs_desc: Not a toy. Real CPU registers, memory management, and computer architecture ‚Äî just expressed in emoji.
welcome.join_desc: OpenKernel is open source and community-driven. We're building the world's most accessible CS education platform, and we need your help. Whether you speak English, Spanish, Arabic, or Mandarin ‚Äî there's a place for you.
welcome.footer: Making computer science accessible to everyone, everywhere.

beginner.title: Beginner Mode
beginner.intro: Choose a guided walkthrough. We'll show you exactly what to tap, step by step. No experience needed!
beginner.code_empty: Your emoji program will appear here...
beginner.wt_hello_desc: Make the computer say 42! Just 3 emoji and you've written real code.
beginner.wt_hello_s1: Let's make the computer say 42! First, tap the glowing LOAD emoji (üì•)
beginner.wt_hello_s1_explain: üì• means LOAD ‚Äî it puts a number into the computer's brain (register R0).
beginner.wt_hello_s2_explain: You just told the computer to load the number 42 into its first register.
beginner.wt_hello_s3: Now let's PRINT it! Tap the PRINT emoji (üñ®Ô∏è)
beginner.wt_hello_s3_explain: üñ®Ô∏è means PRINT ‚Äî it shows whatever number is stored in R0.
beginner.wt_hello_s4: Every program needs to STOP. Tap the HALT emoji (‚èπÔ∏è)
beginner.wt_hello_s4_explain: ‚èπÔ∏è means HALT ‚Äî it tells the computer to stop. Like a period at the end of a sentence!
beginner.wt_hello_s5: Your program is ready! Press the big green RUN button!
beginner.wt_hello_s5_explain: When you press RUN, the computer reads your emoji code line by line and executes it.
beginner.wt_hello_s6: You just wrote your first program! The computer loaded 42, printed it, and stopped.
beginner.wt_hello_s6_explain: That's real programming! Every computer in the world works like this: load data, process it, output results.
beginner.wt_math_desc: Add two numbers together. Load 10, add 5, and get 15!
beginner.wt_math_s1: Let's do math with emoji! First, tap LOAD (üì•)
beginner.wt_math_s1_explain: We start by loading our first number into the computer.
beginner.wt_math_s2_explain: The computer now has 10 in register R0.
beginner.wt_math_s3_explain: ‚ûï means ADD ‚Äî it adds a number to whatever is already in R0.
beginner.wt_math_s4_explain: The computer will add 5 to the 10 already in R0. 10 + 5 = 15!
beginner.wt_math_s5_explain: This will show us the answer.
beginner.wt_math_s6_explain: Always end your programs with HALT.
beginner.wt_math_s7: Press RUN to see the answer!
beginner.wt_math_s7_explain: The computer will execute: LOAD 10, ADD 5, PRINT, HALT.
beginner.wt_math_s8_explain: Real CPUs work exactly like this ‚Äî one operation at a time, modifying registers. You're doing real computer science!
beginner.wt_count_desc: Make the computer count from 5 to 1! Learn loops, jumps, and conditions.
beginner.wt_count_s1: Let's count down from 5! First, tap LOAD (üì•)
beginner.wt_count_s3: Print the current number. Tap PRINT (üñ®Ô∏è)
beginner.wt_count_s3_explain: This prints whatever number is in R0 right now.
beginner.wt_count_s4_explain: ‚ûñ means SUBTRACT ‚Äî it takes a number away from R0.
beginner.wt_count_s5_explain: Each time through the loop, we subtract 1 from our counter.
beginner.wt_count_s6: Now the magic: JUMP IF ZERO. Tap (‚ùì)
beginner.wt_count_s6_explain: ‚ùì checks if R0 is zero. If it IS zero, it jumps to a specific line. This is how computers make decisions!
beginner.wt_count_s7: Type 5 (jump to line 5 ‚Äî the HALT ‚Äî when we reach zero)
beginner.wt_count_s7_explain: When our counter hits 0, we jump to line 5 (HALT) to stop.
beginner.wt_count_s8: Now JUMP back to repeat! Tap JUMP (‚è≠Ô∏è)
beginner.wt_count_s8_explain: ‚è≠Ô∏è means JUMP ‚Äî it goes back to an earlier line. This creates a loop!
beginner.wt_count_s9: Type 1 (jump back to line 1 ‚Äî the PRINT line)
beginner.wt_count_s9_explain: We jump back to line 1 to print the next number and continue the loop.
beginner.wt_count_s10_explain: This is where we land when the counter reaches zero.
beginner.wt_count_s11: Press RUN and watch the countdown!
beginner.wt_count_s11_explain: The computer will loop: print, subtract, check, jump back, until R0 reaches 0.
beginner.wt_count_s12: 5, 4, 3, 2, 1! You just built a loop ‚Äî one of the most powerful concepts in programming!
beginner.wt_count_s12_explain: Loops let computers repeat things millions of times per second. Every video game, every website, every app uses loops.

demos.title: Live Demos
demos.subtitle: See emoji computing in action ‚Äî interactive simulations you can explore
demos.info: These demos are full emoji operating system simulations. They run entirely in your browser ‚Äî no server needed. Boot them up, spawn processes, and watch OS concepts come alive!
demos.demo1_desc: A complete single-process OS kernel. Watch processes spawn, see the CPU pipeline animate, allocate memory, browse the filesystem, and observe real-time scheduling.
demos.demo2_desc: The full emoji operating system: networking with packet routing, device management, virtual memory with paging, a terminal emulator, and emoji assembly programming.
demos.demo3_desc: Hexacore CPU visualization, embedded games (Snake!), calculator app, real-time performance graphs, and system monitoring. See how modern operating systems work.

console.title: Output Console
console.empty: Run a program to see output here

errors.stackUnderflow: Stack is empty - nothing to pop!
errors.memoryOutOfBounds: Memory address {{address}} is out of bounds (0-255)
errors.infiniteLoop: Possible infinite loop detected. Program stopped after {{cycles}} cycles.
errors.noHalt: Your program doesn't have a ‚èπÔ∏è (HALT) instruction at the end.
